title: meteor shower orionids halleys comet space news astrophotography astronomy
story: Mysterious light in the sky: Rare moment meteor EXPLODES above UK skies (Image: NICK JACKSON &bull SWNS)Residents near Clun Castle, Shropshire, we left scratching their heads after spotting a bright light streaking through the clouds.But landscape astro-photographer Nick Jackson was in the right place at the right time as he managed to snap some images of the mysterious object.After spotting the light he instinctively grabbed his camera.Mr Jackson said: &ldquoI immediately thought, 'I hope that was caught in the frame'.                Orionids 2018: How to see Orionid meteor shower TONIGHT                Orionids 2018: What time is the Orionid meteor shower peak tonight?&ldquoIt was a sheer stroke of luck that I just happened to be shooting the series of images when it happened.With things like that, you've got to be in the right place at the right time.The ball of light turned out to be a bright meteor which disintegrated as it impacted Earth&rsquos atmosphere.Our planet is currently passing through the debris trail left by the Halley&rsquos Comet &ndash now more formally known as Comet 1PHalley.Rock and ice falls from the comet, which passes Earth in October every year, burning up as they hit Earth&rsquos atmosphere.The annual event is known as the Orionid meteor shower and this year it peaked on the nights of October 21 and October 22.However, it is rare to capture a shooting star this clearly, and Mr Jackson is pleased to have done so.He said: It's very unusual to see a meteor that big. Because I was shooting the star trail, I couldn't check the footage immediately.The meteor was caused by Halley's Comet (Image: NICK JACKSON &bull SWNS)There are very few images out there that have captured this before. (Image: NICK JACKSON &bull SWNS)There are very few images out there that have captured this before.I posted it on Facebook on some astronomy groups and it just blew up over the weekend.People were saying, 'You're a lucky guy, that's a once-in-a-lifetime thing&rsquo.The reason we photographers go out in the middle of the night and stand there in the freezing cold is because we're obsessed with the beauty of the night sky, its peace and calm.Nick Jackson said he was lucky to capture the image (Image: NICK JACKSON &bull SWNS)And when you see something like that, it's just awe-inspiring.Mr Jackson, from Ludlow, then combined the images into four seconds of footage.He said: To the naked eye, it's over in a flash. You just see a streak of light and a bright ping and then it's gone.However, the camera captures all the detail of the aftermath.

title: nasa announcement news alien discovery extraterrestrial kepler gaia space news
story: NASA announcement shock: Space agency closing in on finding ALIEN LIFE (Image: )The space agency has been scouring the universe in the search for extraterrestrials, and optimistically scientists at NASA believe that every failed attempt draws them a step closer to finding aliens.Missions such as Kepler have discovered thousands of planets across the Milky Way, yet these are described as NASA as a &ldquomotley, teeming multitude: hot Jupiters, gas giants, small, rocky worlds and mysterious planets larger than Earth and smaller than Neptune.The space agency says that it is still searching for the elusive planet which they are sure could host life.And every step is bringing them closer.                ANOTHER UFO spotted in Rendlesham Forest                Scientists to create first extraterrestrialNASA said in a statement: &ldquoAs we prepare to add many thousands more to the thousands found already, the search goes on for evidence of life &ndash and for a world something like our own.&ldquoFuture space telescopes will be able to analyse the light from some of these planets, searching for water or a mixture of gases that resembles our own atmosphere.&ldquoWe will gain a better understanding of temperatures on the surface.&ldquoAs we continue checking off items on the habitability list, we'll draw closer and closer to finding a world bearing recognisable signs of life.NASA credits Europe for helping to narrow down the search thanks to the European Space Agency&rsquos (ESA&rsquos) Gaia satellite.The satellite was launched in July 2013 and has already mapped an astonishing 1.7 billion stars through the Milky Way.It has helped to build on NASA&rsquos Kepler telescope by prompting a reassessment of star sizes to learn whether some might be larger, smaller, dimmer or brighter than scientists had thought.The Gaia spacecraft (Image: ESA)Gaia helped to discover many stars were brighter than previously thought, which in turn would mean the planet&rsquos, found by Kepler, orbiting a larger star will also be bigger too.Eric Mamajek, the deputy program chief scientist for NASA's Exoplanet Exploration Program, said: Gaia has improved distances and has improved assessments of how bright a star is, and how big a planet is.The whole issue has always been, how well do we understand the star? This is just another chapter of that ongoing story.

title: Brexit news Ireland border backstop negotiations EU UK withdrawal latest Theresa May
story: The Irish border resident exploded at Ireland's Government for rolling over in fear to the demands of the European Union.Mr Laighneach claimed Ireland has become a colony of the bloc, accepting its decision without criticism to avoid negative consequences.Speaking to RT UK, the peace activist said: I think the Irish rolled over in fear because our economy&rsquos tiny.I think there&rsquos bad leadership in Ireland, it&rsquos almost got to a stage where the European Union is now the new Holy Catholic Empire and any criticism of it now is almost blasphemy.                Tory Brexiteer claims Brexit not even top five worries for investors                Remainers beg Barnier to kickstart EU plans for a second Brexit voteHe continued: Our problem is we have been the first colony and probably the last colony but we have no concept of how to control our economy separately from these two mad powers.The people of Ireland, we have ceded most of our powers to Europe and that&rsquos evidenced in our inability to stop Europe foisting on us a huge debt in the recent past, which we are still burdened with it.Mr Laighneach's claim comes after Tory MP Andrew Bridgen suggested leaving the EU will become irresistible to the Republic of Ireland once they become a major contributor to EU coffers after Brexit.The MP for North West Leicestershire also pointed to the appeal of free trade deals with the United States as a reason the Republic of Ireland may leave, as well as issues surrounding corporation tax and the military.Brexit news: Mr Laighneach blasted the Irish Government for bowing down to EU demands (Image: RT UK&bull FRANCE INTER)The Brexiteer told Mr Boulton this afternoon: &ldquoWhat the European Union are desperately seeking to avoid is the good people of the Republic of Ireland, who are still in the EU, looking across the virtual border into Northern Ireland.A land of milk and honey, where we&rsquove got tree trade deals with countries around the world, including the USA, which is the Republic of Ireland&rsquos largest trading partner, that they can&rsquot join into.&ldquoBecause what they know is the Republic of Ireland will be leaving the European Union very very quickly.&ldquoEven faster is the EU try to enforce a hard border.                IREXIT: Ireland will be 'DESPERATE' to LEAVE the EUBrexit news: Both the EU and the UK have said they do not want a hard border in Ireland (Image: )The issue of a hard border between the Republic and Northern Ireland has ballooned into a major point of contention during the Brexit negotiations between Britain and the EU.&nbspBrussels has demanded Theresa May agree to a so-called&nbspbackstop&nbsp&ndash a safety net or insurance policy in the event of a collapse in the talks.&nbspBoth sides agree the backstop will need to maintain cross-border cooperation, support the all-island economy and protect the Good Friday peace agreement.The bloc has proposed a backstop that would mean Northern Ireland remains in the EU customs union.Chief negotiator Michel Barnier has continually said this backstop can only apply to Northern Ireland, not the rest of the UK.But the UK is radically opposed to this plan, claiming there will essentially be a customs and regulatory border down the middle of the Irish Sea, cutting off the rest of the UK.

story: The Conservative MSP tore into the Scottish National Party (SNP) after Scottish Brexit Minister Michael Russell suggested the party would be willing to trigger a no deal Brexit.Mr Fraser branded Nicola Sturgeon's party irresponsible for proposals to vote down Theresa May's final withdrawal deal with the European Union.Addressing Mr Russell after an address in the Scottish Parliament, the Tory MSP said: All today&rsquos statement seems to be is another opportunity for yet more grandstanding and grievance for a minister who has become a master in both.The Cabinet Secretary tells us how catastrophic a no deal scenario would be but then astonishingly goes on to say SNP MPs will bring on a no deal scenario by voting against proposals brought forward by the UK Government.                EU citizens handed &pound9MILLION UK fund for Brexit settled-status                 Tory MP dismisses May's post-Brexit plan as 'worst deal ever done'That&rsquos an irresponsible approach and will be seen as such by the people of Scotland.The SNP has threatened to vote down Mrs May's proposed deal in an attempt to pressure the Government into agreeing to a bespoke trade deal with Brussels for Scotland.Ms Sturgeon claimed in June she would seek a special arrangement for the Scottish economy mimicking the future agreement the British Government is expected to secure for Northern Ireland.But Mr Fraser pointed out such an attempt would threaten the integrity of the UK internal market and, subsequently, Scotland's economy.Brexit news: Mr Fraser accused Russell of grandstanding as he presented the irresponsible plan (Image: SCOTTISH PARLIAMENT)He continued: A differentiated deal for Scotland would put at risk the internal UK market which is worth four times more to the Scottish economy than trade with the EU.Mr Russell had previously voiced concern about the apparent lack of planning from the British Government, suggesting the UK is at the brink of a catastrophic no deal outcome.He said: The fact that they are talking of hiring boats, packing motorways with lorries and stockpiling medicines illustrates the vacuum in leadership in the UK, which is resulting in measures unprecedented in peacetime.&ldquoIf the UK Government put our option on the table then we will commit ourselves to support it. But without such a proposal we will reject every other option short of staying in the EU as all deliver a succession of unacceptable and damaging bad deals, or no deal at all.Mr Russell added: The Scottish Government will seek to ensure that this parliament can pass its own judgment on it. On this most crucial of matters, Scotland must be - and will be - heard.

story: The former Chancellor insisted a second Brexit vote would create a permanent ision between British politicians and voters.In a scathing speech targeting the European Union's track record of demanding a re-run when results do not meet the expectations of top Eurocrats, Lord Lamont pointed out British voters had been promised their decision to leave would be respected.Addressing fellow peers in the House of Lords, he said: Tony Blair, who one would have thought could&rsquove used his experience and contacts to help the Government, has said the result of the second referendum would have to be definitive and have to be respected.Big deal. That&rsquos what he said last time, that&rsquos what we were all told about the referendum we had. Danish voters headed for the poll a second time after voting down the Maastricht Treaty in 1992.&nbspLord Lamont continued: Some people say that this would be a healing process. That seems to be the most improbable argument of all. It would create a permanent ision in our politics.Brexit news: Lord Lamont said a second vote would be a disaster for British democracy (Image: BBC&bullPARLIAMENT TV)People already feel they have great disillusionment with our system, disdain for the system is widespread. I believe a second referendum would be a disaster of the first order for democracy.It would undermine the very basis of democracy because it would suggest that a decision by a majority is insufficient to make that decision legitimate.Nearly 700,000 Britons took to the streets of London last week to demand a re-run of the referendum during the so-called People's Vote March.The &ldquoPeople&rsquos Vote is pegged as the public having a &ldquofinal say on the deal negotiated by the Government.London Mayor Sadiq Khan started the march and delivered an address to the crowd, saying: &ldquoWhat&rsquos really important is that those that say that a public vote is undemocratic, is unpatriotic, realise the fact the exact opposite is the truth.&ldquoWhat could be more democratic, what could be more British, than trusting the judgement of the British people.

story: Lisa Nandy, formerly a member of Jeremy Corbyn&rsquos Shadow Cabinet, made the shock announcement on the BBC&rsquos Question Time show.Referring to Theresa May, she said: &ldquoIf she can solve this problem of deadlock on the Northern Irish border by standing up to the small group of hard Brexiteers in her party and bringing forward a UK-wide customs arrangement that works for the whole country, then I believe we should vote for that.The intervention is significant as Mrs May may require some Labour support to get a Brexit deal through Parliament, as some in her own party and the DUP are threatening to vote against it.It would likely mean rebelling against the Labour Party leadership, which has suggested it will oppose any likely deal. A withdrawal agreement that involves a UK-wide customs agreement that protects jobs in every constituency in the UK and helps us solve the problems of the Northern Irish border.Lisa Nandy MP appeared on Question Time last night  (Image: BBC QUESTION TIME)Last night's Question Time came from Barrow-in-Furness (Image: BBC QUESTION TIME)&ldquoBut that would require the courage of Theresa May to stand up to this small group of MPs who are holding both her and the rest of the country to ransom.Numerous Conservative MPs have indicated they could refuse to back a Brexit deal which looks similar to Mrs May&rsquos proposed Chequers plan.Steve Baker MP, who resigned as a Minister in the Department for Exiting the European Union (DExEU) over Chequers, told the BBC up to 80 Tories could vote against such a deal.He warned that attempting to push such a deal through would result in a &ldquocatastrophic split within the Conservative Party.                &lsquoReserved for British fishermen!' story: Mr Hannan made the shock comments during an interview with&nbspExpress.He said: &ldquoI was a very prominent critic of the EU for 20 years and I&rsquove seen people who are on the other side who have now stopped talking to me, who were always on perfectly good terms until the referendum.&ldquoIt&rsquos not a very British way of behaving and I&rsquom quite shocked by it.Mr Hannan has been a member of the European Parliament since 1999.                &lsquoWe could TAKE Falklands back after Brexit&rsquo- Argentinian government                 Brexit shock: Raab tells EU there will be NO DEAL if they delayThe longstanding Brexit advocate has written numerous books and articles on why the UK should leave the EU.Mr Hannan went on to explain why he thinks the referendum produced such intolerance.He argued: &ldquoI think it was the psychological shock of not getting their way on something.&ldquoThey are accustomed to politics having happened within certain parameters, in June 2016 those parameters were blown away.&ldquoIt&rsquos not a very British way of behaving and I&rsquom quite shocked by it (Image: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT)Anti-Brexit protestors in London on Saturday (Image: )&ldquoDuring the campaign Remainers decided the &lsquoLeave&rsquo case was reactionary, small-minded, anti-immigrant and so on.&ldquoBy polling day I think they&rsquod come to believe their own propaganda.After the referendum Mr Hannan became President of the newly formed Initiative for Free Trade, which campaigns for free trade around the world.However, he is concerned about the ongoing Brexit negotiations, and is particularly adamant that the UK must not end up in a customs union with the EU.                &lsquoOnly a Brexiteer can deliver Brexit&rsquo - Tory in anti-May tirade                 &lsquoI could back May Brexit deal&rsquo - Labour MP in INCREDIBLE admission&ldquoDuring the campaign Remainers decided the &lsquoLeave&rsquo case was reactionary (Image: )He claimed: &ldquoStaying in the customs union, giving Brussels 100 percent control over our trade policy without any input as to what that trade policy should be, that is worse that either staying or leaving.&ldquoIt is absolutely the worst of all worlds.&ldquoIt&rsquos really important to understand quite how awful this situation would be.Earlier this month it was reported that Theresa May was considering a proposal which would keep the UK in a customs union with the EU for a period after Brexit.Brexit negotiations between the UK and EU are reaching a critical stage (Image: )Some Eurosceptics feared this relationship could become permanent.According to Mr Hannan this would see the UK automatically signed up to EU trade deals, and having to make any concessions the EU negotiated, without getting all the benefits in return.He argued that for the EU the UK would become &ldquoa bargaining chip in their trade negotiations with third countries.

title: make this budget philips last
story: Next Monday, on the eve of Halloween, Phil Hammond will raise the curtain on his latest tax-hiking non-Tory Budget.If there’s any justice, it will be his last.If Theresa May’s Downing Street days are numbered, so should those be of her Death Watch Chancellor.Together, they are the unrivalled stars of Tory MP Johnny Mercer’s glorious Whitehall farce, “The Sh*t Show”.Excitable critics say Mrs May is entering a “killing zone”.Rivals jockey for position while party chiefs try to streamline the timetable for picking her successor.This Prime Minister’s Number Ten tenancy is almost up. So is Hammond’s next door.Whoever takes over — Boris, David Davis or Jeremy Hunt — needs an emergency clear-out.The big guns of the Treasury need to be pointed at the “enemy” not its own side.After two long, wasted years, Britain is engaged in an unexpectedly desperate fight, not just to salvage Brexit but to save British democracy.Weekend crowds demanding a second referendum seem oblivious to the threat such a crazy re-run would pose to this nation’s centuries-old stability, ironically the envy of Europe.We cannot reverse the  referendum without turning Brexit into a perpetual running sore. And Britain can never rejoin the EU except on its knees.The only way to put this corrosive issue to bed is for Brexit to succeed — as it will, despite treacherous Tony Blair and Facebook hypocrite Nick Clegg.To succeed as we must we need a new chancellor as well as a new prime minister.Diehard Remainer Phil Hammond should be first out the door.It was Spreadsheet Phil who vetoed vital preparations for No Deal — now a better-than - prospect with time rapidly running out.And it was Hammond who surrendered the one negotiating weapon Brussels fears most — a thriving, low-tax Britain competing with the EU on its doorstep.Our economic fate is entirely in our hands. We can make taxes and tarfs as competitive as we like.Better investment incentives and lower corporation tax rates would trigger a flood of foreign investment in UK plc — and ensure car makers like Nissan and Toyota never leave our shores.Yet the British Chancellor of the Exchequer has ruled them out.“Phil is like those Harry Potter Dementor creatures,” says a top Tory. “He sucks the le out of any room he happens to be in.”Hammond is easily replaced. Michael Gove, an ex-future PM but a formidable Cabinet minister, has the drive and imagination to take on the Treasury “Blob”.There is no shortage of Brexit talent on the Tory benches.Just compare thundering Attorney General Geoffrey Cox QC with prissy dried-stick predecessor Dominic Grieve.Grieve is busy sabotaging Brexit. Cox finds ways to make it work.He is now “marking Number Ten’s homework” on Mrs May’s wretched Northern Ireland “backstop”.Some even tip him as a dark horse in the leadership stakes.There is one other big change needed at the heart of Britain’s Brexit team.Our next PM must have a new EU negotiator.Nobody could be worse than Olly Robbins, already reportedly eyeing up a £m-a-year golden parachute into a top City job.Lelong Europhile Robbins has led Mrs May into so many disastrous EU traps — especially her humiliation in Salzburg — he is often cast as an EU “double agent”.It was Robbins who told EU negotiator Michel Barnier that Britain might stay indefinitely in “transition” while the fantasy Northern Ireland backstop was sorted out.And pay £bn more on top of the £bn ransom for the privilege.The idea that Robbins is the “EU’s man in Whitehall” is not such a stretch when you consider his Jeremy Corbyn-style applause for Communist Russia.Kremlin leaders, he told fellow Oxford students in , “changed Russia from a backward peasant autocracy, despised by the West, into a technological giant at whom the world cowered in fear for half a century.”Everyone is entitled to youthful naivety.But can anyone imagine Olly Robbins fighting our corner for EU democracy and accountability, let alone the referendum verdict of .m Brexit-voting Brits SAUDI Arabia’s rulers must be really annoyed with dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.This elderly trouble maker walked alone into his country’s Turkish consulate knowing he might never emerge alive.He was clearly looking for trouble.Once inside, using his bare hands, he attacked a gang of  innocent Saudi torturers who had just flown in for a couple of hours’ holiday armed only with a bone saw and a hypodermic syringe.Then, to the embarrassment of kindly Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, he went and hid his own body.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: go vape e cigs better than regular cigarettes
story: But it isn’t.They also think that because you are inhaling nicotine in the vapour of e-cigarettes you are just as likely to get lung cancer as you would smoking tobacco.You are not.There are also worries that vaping will act as a gateway for young people, who have never smoked, to progress to traditional cigarettes and ruin their health as a result.They are fears, too, that it will “normalise” smoking again just when public health campaigns are managing to help more people permanently quit smoking than ever before.All the evidence, however, says that this just is not the case.Don’t get me wrong, as a doctor I’d prefer itnobody smoked OR vaped.Years ago, as medical students, who should have known better, many of us smoked a little — often to disguise the awful, lingering smell of the cadavers we had to dissect in the anatomy room.But we soon stopped when we saw with our own eyes what the long-term effects of smoking did to the human body.In the Pathology Museum we would see a nice healthy pink lung sat pickled in a jar of formaldehyde right next to another lung, black with tar and soot from smoking, at the centre of which was a hard, pearly white grapefruit-sized knuckle of cancer with tentacles reaching out into other adjacent organs including the liver and brain.Smoking kills.Later, as qualied doctors on the wards, we saw the horrendous consequences of it.People who could not breathe without oxygen tanks, people suffering heart attacks or strokes, or undergoing amputations or voicebox removal for throat cancer.We saw — and still see — the damage done to unborn babies of expectant mothers, who remain addicted, and the increased risk of chest and ear infections from passive smoking, and meningitis and leukaemia in infants, who live in smoking households.The medical evidence is irrefutable. Smoking tobacco is bad news.But vaping is dferent.You heat up a solution called an e-liquid, which typically contains nicotine, a propellant called propylene glycol and or vegetable glycerin and flavourings.What you don’t do is burn tobacco or produce tar or carbon monoxide — two of the most harmful elements of all in tobacco smoke.Sure, some vapes may contain a fraction of some of the harmful chemicals found in cigarette smoke, but they are present at much lower levels,detectable at all.So are they safe  According to all the international medically-reviewed evidence from such expert organisations as Public Health England, the Royal Colleges of Physicians and General Practitioners, the British Medical Association and Cancer Research UK, e-cigarettes are at least  per cent safer than traditional cigarettes.The American Cancer Society and the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine both agree with them.Yes, the nicotine, of course, is addictive. But so what  So is caffeine, even eating.Contrary to popular belief, nicotine does not give you cancer and it is relatively harmless generally.Apparently only  per cent of the population know this.Happily, there is no evidence of harm to other people from vaping and,used instead of nicotine replacement gum or patches, may even help expectant mums remain smoke-free in the long term.As a doctor I don’t want any young person or non-nicotine user to try vaping. Ever. Period.As it happens, regular use of e-cigs among “never” smokers is still very rare at just . per cent.But look at what they’ve done to help tobacco smokers quit.In the UK, .million vapers have quit smoking completely and more than , have given up both smoking and vaping.In fact, this is Britain’s most popular method of quitting with two-thirds stopping successfully when used alongside professional stop-smoking NHS support.In this country we have some of the strictest regulations in the world.E-cigs are subject to minimum standards of quality and safety as well as clear packaging and labelling requirements.All ingredients have to be notied, advertising is prohibited in media such as television, newspapers and magazines, it is illegal to sell them to under s and to adults intending to pass them on to under s.That is responsible regulation whichever way you look at it.This month’s national Stoptober campaign recommends using e- cigarettes as a stop-smoking aid andit helps some of the million smokers in the UK kick the habit for good then perhaps doctors like me will see fewer people in our surgeries struggling to breath or devastated by a cancer diagnosis.AndI see any ex-smoking patients of mine having a quiet vape outside my surgery door, I shall give them a heartfelt pat on the back and cherish the fact that there will be one less nasty fag end polluting the street.NICOTINE contained in e-liquids is a highly addictive substance that raises blood pressure and spikes your adrenalin, increasing the chances of having a heart attack.This is particularly worrying as we see a number of iniduals who are constantly vaping, especially as it is seen as more convenient and cost-effective than lighting up a cigarette, as well as being considered more socially acceptable to vape indoors.While vaping appears to be safer than cigarettes, the truth is that it hasn’t been around long enough for us to know the potential damage it can cause to our health.The long-term effects of the chemicals contained in e-liquids haven’t been examined.However, I have looked into ious research that has been carried out on certain e-liquids that were found to contain substances that can cause damage to the immune system and are linked to other health conditions such as cancer.Vaping isn’t great for your oral health either.It’s common for vaping to cause a dry mouth, and I’ve met a number of iniduals who have developed oral thrush, most likely caused by vaping.Although nicotine does not have a colour, it becomes yellow when combined with oxygen which could lead to tooth discolouration.As nicotine is a vasocon-strictor, it limits blood flow in oral tissue, which can cause gum disease and bad breath.As time goes on, I am reading new research which proves vaping has a negative effect on health.To what extent, only time will tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Not least from Tom himself, perhaps, whose first we Mimi Rogers bemoaned the lack of intimacy in their union because, she claims, he wanted to be a monk and “thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument, but my instrument needed tuning, and we had to split.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. That means being a part of a global economy. One in which the Japanese can build cars in the North East, American outfits can trade in the City and, yes, navy blue British passports can be made in France.Protectionism is a race to the bottom.BRITAIN now has the fourth lowest rate of home ownership in the EU.It is a damning indictment of decades of failed housing policy. Next week’s Budget is a chance for a radical sea change to ensure our property-owning democracy survives for generations.Don’t blow it, Chancellor.MPs shouldn’t have to march on Downing Street to end the witch-hunt against Northern Ireland veterans.But the PM and Cabinet must listen.The disgraceful pursuit must stop.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: freedom of the press sun says gagging claims
story: Yesterday, it was revealed that the Dailyhas been stopped from revealing the name of a prominent businessman who — on at least five occasions — has used non-disclosure agreements and hush money to silence allegations against him.Is it in the public interest for a loaded businessman to be able to silence the Press by spending half a million quid on legal proceedings Or for the public to know what he’s been accused of, and paid handsome sums to keep it quiet Ask yourself this:a member of your family was applying for a job working for him, wouldn’t you want to know The #MeToo scandal showed just how far powerful figures will go to keep their victims schtum. But it’s not just Harvey Weinstein and Hollywood.Over the past year, we’ve seen the High Court impose serious reporting restrictions on police arrests and a bid by Press-hating tycoon Max Mosley to wipe his fascist past out of history citing the ‘right to be forgotten’.It will be you, the public, who lose outthe rich and powerful stop us doing our job.GIVE us a date, Prime Minister.No, not for your departure. But for the end of the transition period.We are wary of it lasting a day beyond .If the PM has any hope of getting a deal through Parliament, the transition must have a legally-binding end date.Anything less would be the definition of a bad deal — and no deal is better than a bad deal.DOES John Bercow have no shame With every day he sits in the Speaker’s chair he discredits Parliament.His refusal to take allegations of bullying and harassment seriously is an embarrassment at the heart of our democracy.Parliament has a ready-made replacement for this rhino-hided oaf in Lindsay Hoyle — respected across the House.Bercow must go. Now.TURKISH supremo Recep Erdogan can spare us the holier than thou act on human rights.What happened to Jamal Khashoggi at the hands of the Saudis is disgraceful. But Erdogan’s record of political purges and locking up journalists is not far off.He has more in common with the regime in Riyadh than he’d like to think.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dog pretended stray begged food outside mcdonalds
story: Betsy Reyes of Oklahoma City, USA says Princess sneaks out at night and lingers outside her local fast food restaurant in the hope customers will feed her.In a Facebook post that has since gone viral, Reyes shared a photo of Princess saying: “If you see my dog @ the McDonald’s on shields, quit feeding her fat ass bc she don’t know how to act  be leaving the house all the time to go walking to McDonald’s at night.“She’s not even a stray dog.”Reyes decided that sharing the image on Facebook was simply not enough, and drove to catch the pet in the act at her local McDonalds on Monday night, reported Time.She caught her dog waiting to bed fed by other customers. In the video, a woman in her car appears to throw Princess some food from the window.She posted the video, writing: “When I caught her ass in the act.”As she pulled up to the driveway, her dog immediately recognised her and started wagging her tail before jumping up and down in excitement.The hilarious posts racked up more than k likes on Facebook, and has over k comments.Many comments have labelled Princess as a “a”, while others called her “smart” and “funny”.The dog received some serious recognition, and even had a fan account made for her on Instagram called dogatmacdonald.Others took the opportunity to transform the original picture of Princess into a hilarious meme.

title: picture deer hiding forest
story: The colour of the little fawns coat blends perfectly with the background keeping it camouflaged and safe from predators.The little deer was unwittingly caught on camera by photograher Ingo Gerlach, , who failed to spot it as he was looking at two stags rutting in the distance.It was only later that his pictures revealed the hidden animal nestled close to a clump of tree stumps and fallen trees just feet away from him.Ingo said: The young stag really adapted well to his surroundings which is why he is so hard to spot.I couldnt believe it when I realised the young deer had been right in front of me.He must have been hiding from the older deer who can be quite aggressive when in rut.The young stag was snapped in front of a forest in the Sauerland region in Germany.The rut is a part of the mating season where male deer have a large increase in testosterone which leads them to be more aggressive and sometimes violent.

title: rogue landlords
story: His landlord was desperate to drive him out, and had switched off all the electricity to his Kensal Rise flat in north-west London, meaning hed been forced to live in the dark, causing the atrocious accident.Daud - who is blind in one eye and originally from Somalia -managed to crawl naked and bleeding onto the street, where a neighbour discovered him and called an ambulance.The -year-old spent  days in a West London hospital - four in the major trauma ward – with swelling to his spinal cord that caused numbness.The rogue landlord is just one of many operating in Britain today, but Dauds case highlights just how low some landlords will stoop to make their tenants lives hell.Things got even worse when Daud was discharged and found he had no home to go back to.His landlord sent him a brutal a message via family members, which said: “Tell that black bastard that I have evicted him and his s**t is outside.”When Daud ed to the dismal property he called home, the locks had been changed and his belongings removed from the flat where his unscrupulous landlord had been trying to force him out by disconnecting the electricity and removing the meter.I called my landlord, Bernard McGowan, to say I was outside my property and homeless. He laughed at me, Daud tells Sun Online.He later took McGowan to court and won damages, but his local council didn’t prosecute.“I will never forget that night as long as I live,” Daud says.“I went home at pm in a neck brace to find all my worldly possessions, including a ripped photo of my mum on her wedding day in Somalia, thrown into the street.“I had nowhere to go, and that night I felt suicidal. I saw no point in living.A friend offered him a temporary place to stay.Three years on, Daud, now , is proudly running his own community centre in Brent - All Nations - helping people from all ethnic backgrounds with problems such as the one he experienced. He also has a council property to call home.“That night changed my le and made me realise that I was going to have to start my le all over again. I love helping people and I am proud of the work I do.”Property owner Bernard McGowan boasts of having a £m portfolio but has been convicted six times since , and was fined more than £, for property offences last year.His tenants have complained of intimidation, electricity being disconnected, locks being changed and deposits never being ed - and of forced evictions from homes riddled with cold, damp and vermin, sometimes with beds and personal possessions strewn outside the front doors.Many of McGowan’s tenants are vulnerable. Erskine Clarke was sleeping rough before the council housed him in a West London property costing almost £ a week for a ft x ft room in a shared house with mould, a faulty boiler and a leaking toilet.Erskine says requests for repairs to McGowan were ignored, and the boiler problem went on for two years, resulting in no heating or hot water.He still lives at the property but now has a new landlord who is renovating it.The scarred tenant adds: “Nobody should be living in the state it was in. It made me depressed. I lost a lot of weight and got very sick. Why does the government let people do this But sadly, Doud and Erskine arent the only tenants suffering.Between  and , landlord Gary Fixter, , failed to act on repeated warnings to improve the standard of his properties, despite collecting £, a year in rent and earning a salary of £, a year as an IT consultant.He pleaded guilty to  offences between  and , with eight convictions for renting out substandard shared houses, often without heating, water supplies or fire alarms.He rented out a shed for £ a month, a property with live wires spilling out from the mains electrical unit, and another infested with rats.One of those hoping for justice for private rental tenants is -year-old Askel Douglas, who last year was spending every penny of his £ a week universal credit on a Neasden flat above a supermarket in London which flooded three times.“I was totally ripped off by my private landlord, Askel, who has now moved, told The Sun Online.There was water coming out of the walls and ceilings so it was knee-deep and a total mess, and stinking, dirty water was coming up through the plug so I couldn’t even have a bath.Jacky Peacock OBE, is director of London charity AdviceRenters, which is campaigning for reform of the private renting sector.She and her colleagues regularly witness the appalling standards in domestic renting which can be so bad they make tenants ill.“The things I see are atrocious. Filthy flats in a state of complete disrepair, but also we see many problems with overcrowding,” Jacky told The Sun Online.“People are exploited by employers as well as landlords, often migrant workers who are hardly paid anything, and they end up in these dreadful places, trying to raise their children.“We recently saw a Hungarian couple who lived with their six-year-old child in one small room. The husband was a mini cab driver who worked all hours to earn money for them, and he came back to the property one day to find the landlord had let himself into the room and was molesting his we.“The landlord brandished a kitchen kne and tried to stab the tenant – this is the kind of atrocious thing we’re seeing day after day. It makes me so angry that vulnerable people are exploited like this.”Access to a ing, clean kitchen can be dficult when people are crowded into one property.“We were in a flat last week where the sink leaked, so every time the tap went on, the downstairs flat was flooded. The landlord had been to fix it but basically he’d just propped it up,” says Jacky.She believes a flood of amateur landlords – buy-to-let owners investing in property with no knowledge of their legal responsibilities – are making the problem worse.AdviceRenters is urging the government to introduce and enforce a national regulatory scheme for the private rental sector.The charity shared a series of recent photographs with The Sun Online, all of them taken in London properties in shocking states of disrepair.They show damp, rotten fire escapes, leaking toilets, sinks and showers and boarded-up windows.Tenants suffering at the hands of unscrupulous landlords are often on low incomes or benefits - people with no bargaining power and little choice as to where they live. They’re crammed into houses in large and dangerous numbers andthey complain, they’re evicted.A grim roster of greedy iniduals taking cruel advantage of society’s most vulnerable has been revealed in an investigation by ITV News.Rogue landlords are collecting rents – often funded by taxpayers via housing benefit – despite being convicted of housing offences and failing to pass the “fit and proper” person tests required by housing legislation in England and Wales.Because of the way the law is written, this is usually perfectly legal.The government’s efforts to police rogue landlords have been branded “weak” and “pathetic” after the investigation found convicted landlords continuing to operate through loopholes in the law.In response, Heather Wheeler MP, the minister for housing and homelessness, has said: “Everyone deserves a decent and safe place to live, and we are reforming the private rented sector to make it fairer for all.”Angry tenant Askel blasts: “I can’t understand why the government lets people like me get ripped off for every penny we have.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mexico pyramid of the moon hidden tunnels
story: Researchers have revealed they discovered a new tunnel and a cavity hidden below an archaeological site near Mexico City.Details of the stunning discoveries were given in a statement from the investigators of the National Institute of Anthropology and History.Veronica Ortega, the director of the Project of Integral Conservation of Plaza de la Luna, which is the central square in the complex, said the investigation is focused on a ritual space linked to the underworld.Mrs Ortega said the investigation into the cavity, which is believed to have been used as a chamber, will allow them to determine the connections that this old metropolis had with other regions of Mesoameric.The discovery of the chamber and tunnel is a result of a initial study using electrical resistivity carried out around the Pyramid of the Moon in June .Electric resistivity methods are a form of geophysical surveying which help create an image of the subsurface. These methods utilise dferences in electric potential to identy subsurface material. The cavity, which experts believe could have been dedicated to rituals, is  feet below the pyramid and is  feet in diameter.The tunnel is located towards the south of the Plaza de la Luna and experts believe there could be another entry to the east.The Pyramid of the Moon is the second largest pyramid in Mexico after the Pyramid of the Sun. Its structure existed prior to  AD.Studies from  gave an indication of the possible existence of a chamber and the archaeologists have now confirmed the existence of the chamber.The city of Teotihuacan is believed to have been established around  BCE.It is believed to have been built by the Toltec before the Aztecs arrived.In research carried out in the late s at the site archaeologists Ruben Cabrera and Saburo Sugiyama discovered skeletons with cranial deformations along with objects from green stone.

title: salisbury poppy christmas tree
story: Critics vented their fury on social media after the artwork went on show in Salisbury.One tweet described the red tree as tasteless, while a further tweet said it was disrespectful.Another tweeted: Oh dear, this was such a mistake, wrong on so many levels.Old George Malls poppy tree forms part of First World War centenary events planned to take place in the Wiltshire city.Centre manager Jon Osgood said he hoped the display would encourage people to learn more about war and also encourage them to donate to the Royal British Legion. He said: Weve had very positive reactions to the tree across our social media s and through feedback from staff.But Dominic Cox disagreed, tweeting: People are really starting to forget the meaning of rememberance. Things like this turn into a joke. The use of poppies causes controversy each year ahead of Rememberance Day on November .Public figures who opt not to wear them are often accused of lacking respect, while some people feel wearing a poppy is political.In , Asda removed a tribute showing a dead soldier lying beside a tree of poppies from one of its supermarkets after it was deemed disgusting.

title: firms poppy trinkets forces charities
story: Some cash in by mentioning the Royal British Legion, whose Poppy Appeal began yesterday, despite having no official links.One, Scarlett Jewellery, called its baubles — including a £ gold charm — a “symbol of remembrance, a symbol of the Royal British Legion to never forget those we lost”.And Shrieking Violet says its items, one a teardrop charm, are “perfect for remembrance”.Another firm, Poppyshopliveon.org.uk, even uses a web address similar to the Legion’s Poppyshop.org.uk.Its pages feature forces pictures and the slogan “Lest we forget”.It claims proceeds from its gems “benefit the British Legion”.But customers who asked were just told it gave “ten to  per cent” to good causes, with no confirmation any went to the Legion.Elizabeth Minder, , a Legion fundraiser and poppy seller in Redhill, Surrey, said: “It makes my blood boil.“Profiteering from such an honourable cause is saddening. It’s stooping low to earn from the dead.”TV channel QVC, an official ­Legion partner, was also rapped for giving just a third of proceeds and hiding that in small print.Items include £ brooches with the dates  and  to mark the Armistice Day centenary.Its website urges buyers to “wear the poppy and support The Royal British Legion and Poppyscotland”.Legion supporter Ron Grenald, , of Hants, rapped: “You would never know they gave that small an amount unless you looked for it.It’s disgraceful.
