title: argentina exploit no deal brexit falklands britain
story: The country’s foreign minister Jorge Faurie said his country would use the situation to “enhance” its own diplomatic push to take over the islands.Talking to the , Mr Faurie said once the UK leaves the European Union, all EU treaties will no longer apply and member states wont be obliged to support the UK’s claim over the South Atlantic territory.He said: “Our planning for Las Malvinasis to have a negotiation that will enable stronger relations between the people on the islands and the people on the continent.“And we hope that the non Brexitsolution will enhance the possibility of that dialogue to be truly one with results.”Mr Faurie suggested Argentina could take advantage of looser diplomatic ties between the UK and EU as part of its ongoing bid to take control of the Falklands.Mr Faurie said: “If you think member states [of the EU] would not sustain the Malvinas claim in favour of the UK, we are there ... to talk, to negotiate, to see what would be the best solution for the people in the islands to be much more in touch with Argentina.”It comes amid growing uncertainty over the legal status of the UKs overseas territories.Under the EU’s  Lisbon Treaty, the Falkland Islands are a British overseas territory where EU rules apply.The EU’s Duty of Sincere Cooperation includes a a mutual legal obligation for the EU member states to help each other over any claims over sovereignty.Mr Faurie, on a visit to the UK, reiterated his position that the Falklands, which Britain went to war over in , should be integrated into mainland Argentina.UK Prime Minister Theresa May is due to meet Argentinian president Mauricio Macri at the G in Buenos Aires on November .This would be the first visit by a British prime minister to Argentina since Tony Blair in .

title: thomas markle meghan markle baby legal team
story: The Duchess of Sussex’s father, , says the baby will have “Markle blood” as well as “blue blood”, according to reports.Mexico-based Thomas may even force visiting rights by hiring a legal team, the Daily Mirror claim.He has apparently asked help from the Palace and Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby.A source told the paper: “He strongly believes the baby should be as much a part of his le as they will be Prince Charles’s.“Thomas says the Markle blood will be as much in the child’s veins as the ‘blue blood’ of the royals and he has ‘rights’.He admits mistakes but with Meghan pregnant, he is desperate to heal the rt.Thomas has reached out to Kensington Palace more so since news of Meghan’s pregnancy broke, hoping the baby will be what finally breaks their estrangement.”Thomas wants to fly to London and meet Meghan and the Prince, , in person.Previously he likened the Royal Family to Scientologists because of their “cult-like” secrecy.Thomas, an Emmy-winning lighting director, has tried to encourage Meghan and her husband to contact him — after three months of silence.They have not spoken since the day after the couple’s wedding at Windsor Castle.He has offered to fly to the UKhe can sit down with Megha,  and Harry, , when they are back from their South Pacic tour.Yesterday, Meghans half-sister has claimed the Duchess lied about paying her own university fees.Bitter Samantha Markle claimed pregnant Meghan was delusionally absurd.Her comments came as the Duchess of Sussex told a crowd in Fiji she had used scholarships and financial aid programmes to pay her way through.

title: vince cable brexit strictly come dancing
story: The Lib Dem leader # who appeared on the show in  # was last night accused of “Project Fear with tassels” by Leave-voting MPs.Sir Vince says post-Brexit immigration rules could force out the show#s popular dancers, he told the .And he was speaking with experience, having competed in the  Christmas special.But critics, including Jacob Rees-Mogg described his comments as #silly#.After a meeting at the European Commission in Brussels on Thursday, Mr Cable begged EU negotiator Michel Barnier to give Britain time for a second referendum.He said: #As British society falls apart it could pose a risk to Strictly.“If we have a cack-handed immigration policy like what we have for non-EU citizens all kinds of perverse decisions could be made.”Out of Strictly#s current batch of glam dancers, five are British, four are from the EU and nine come from where.Sir Vince claimed the UK would have to #ringfence the citizenship arrangements to protect them.”Jacob Rees-Mogg replied: #The idea that Brexit will have any effect on Strictly is simply silly.“I wouldn’t hold myself up as an expert on Strictly. I watched it when Ed Balls was on it but never since.#He added: “But it is hard to see that immigration rules are key to the success of Strictly or otherwise.“There are already effective and efficient immigration provisions for artists such as opera singers and ballet dancers.”Andrew Bridgen, the MP for North West Leicestershire, said, “Since the majority of Strictly professional dancers are non-EU citizens, I am sure we will have no problem with dealing with EU citizens in the same way after Brexit.”“This is more desperate Project Fear with tassels on it from Vince Cable,” Mr Bridgen said, “it is surely time that he waltzes off into retirement.”Still an avid dancer, Vince Cable recently reached the final of the over-’s British ballroom competition.He was in Brussels with Ian Blackford, the leader of SNP MPs  and Liz Saville Roberts, the Westminster leader of Plaid Cymru.

title: meghan markle prince harry plane abort landing sydney airport
story: The Qantas jet pulled up moments before touching down at Sydney Airport after spotting another aircraft on the runway.The royal couples plane can be seen swooping down towards the ground with its wheels lowered as it prepares to land.But it suddenly lts back up with just seconds to spare after co-pilot Ann Cole realised the runway wasnt clear.The plane - which got as low as ft before aborting the landing - then circled back round to attempt it again, this time touching down safely.There were around  people on board the special charter flight from Tonga.All Harry and Meghan’s staff were on the plane, including a number of politan police protection officers and around  journalists.Captain Nigel Rosser spoke to passengers when the plane climbed back into the air after the aborted landing.He said: “It was a missed approach.“There was an aircraft on the runway that was a little bit slow to roll and unfortunately hadn’t cleared the runway.“We were too close and the decision was made to abort the landing.“So for the second time today you’ll get great views of the harbour.“We’ll get you there safely as soon as possible.”Journalists on the flight tweeted to reveal the drama.ABC News reporter James Longman tweeted: “Missed approach for the Royal Charter back into Sydney.“Another plane on the runway getting in the way. So we’re coming around again.”Hello! royal editor Emily Nash added: “The pilot on Harry and Meghan’splane just had to abort the landing in Sydney seconds from wheels down because of another plane on the runway.“Superb safe second attempt by @qantas Captain Nigel Rosser.”The slight delay means the royal couple may have to rush to attend the Australian Geographic Society Awards to be held at Sydney’s Shangri-La Hotel tonight.The pair are ing to Australia for only a quick visit.After tonight’s event their only official engagement will be tomorrow’s Invictus Games closing ceremony.But the royal tour will continue with Prince Harry and Meghan flying to New Zealand on Sunday.Kensington Palace declined to comment on the aborted landing.Sun Online has contacted Qantas for comment.Meghan and Harry earlier left from Tonga after finishing their tour of the paradise Pacic isle.The mum-to-be cried tears of laughter after school kids sang a comedy song about mosquitoes before they left.She was pictured in hysterics as The Tupou College Boys choir used flying actions and buzzing noises to serenade her and husband Harry.

title: how sir philip green has repeatedly shown flashes of his notorious temper in public
story: The retail boss, who owns stores such as Topshop, Miss Selfridge and Dorothy Perkins, was yesterday unmaksed as the man behind a gagging order over harassment and bullying claims.However while he categorically denies the allegations, recent public outbursts have been caught on camera showing him launch into bizarre rants and even a heated scuffle.In  the mogul was tracked to his super-yacht in Ithaca, Greece, as he soaked up the sun amid the controversial collapse of BHS.After being approached by Sky News reporter David Bowden, he told him to go away and threatened to call the police.The mogul then launched himself at the camera, gesticulating wildly and warning: Thats going in the f***ing sea.Bowden had asked him: People will want to know why youre on holiday when they think you should be sorting out the pension deficit.Sky News said that, off-camera, the pair eventually calmed down and shook hands - but just weeks earlier Sir Philip was involved in another tempertous exchange with MPs.He left members of the Select Committee stunned when he turned to co-chair Frank Field and asked him to get “your lady” — Labour’s Karen Buck — to stop giving him a hard time.Sir Philip also stopped at one point to demand Tory backbencher Richard Fuller “stop staring” at him.The under-fire businessman said: “Sir, do you mind not looking at me like that all the time, it’s really disturbing. Sorry, do you just want to stare at me, it’s making me uncomfortable that’s all.”Mr Fuller replied: “I wasn’t quite just staring at you but I don’t want to make you uncomfortable. I don’t wish to make you uncomfortable.He then told Horsham MP Jeremy Quin to put your glasses back on, you look better with your glasses on.When another MP on the committee asked himhe would prevent somebody buying BHS as it could hurt his ego, he blasted: Oh come on please, thats an insult.You know thats really rude. I find that really rude [...] Im glad the meeting is ending, I think thats disgusting.The chairman of the House of Commons Work and Pensions Committee Frank Field, who led condemnation of Sir Philip over his treatment of BHS pensioners, said: The charge sheet against the knighthood is growing.Parliament and the country have made their views clear on this matter. Ultimately its a decision for the Honours Forfeiture Committee.Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable said Sir Philip narrowly and luckily escaped losing his knighthood over the pensions scandal.And he added: If these allegations are correct, he should certainly be stripped of his knighthood.Mr Field said he would push for the creation of a new procedure allowing MPs to raise abuse cases in Parliament.I am seeking to raise urgently with the Government the importance of having a mechanism in Parliament through which the voices of victims of abuse can be heard, said the Birkenhead MP.This would develop the role of the House of Commons in a way which stands up for people who have little money, against those who have much.Lord Hain said he had received overwhelming support - particularly from women after making his shock statement to the House of Lords.The recent allegations against Sir Philip do not mark the first time workers have spoken out about his alleged conduct.An anonymous employee in  wrote for the : Hatred is a terrible thing, but I have no idea what other response there could possibly be to a man such as Philip Green.The man is like a cancer: seemingly determined to grow and spread his little empire with no concern whatsoever for the effect that it may have on others.Sir Philip was unmasked yesterday by former cabinet minister Lord Hain, who used the protection of parliamentary privilege to identy the Arcadia chairman as the inidual behind a legal injunction preventing The Dailyfrom publishing confidential information from five employees.The paper reported that the tycoon is a the centre of #MeToo allegations including sexual harassment and racial abuse.He he said he categorically and wholly denied being guilty of any unlawful sexual or racist behaviour, in a statement issued hours after the Labour peers dramatic intervention in the House of Lords.

title: people wont be putting clocks back
story: Many don’t even realise they will wake up on Sunday morning after getting an extra hour of sleep.That is because more than half of UK adults,  per cent, no longer use analogue timepieces or technology.Brits will be waking up on Sunday morning to a home full of digital devices and Internet-connected phones, computers, TVs and appliances that will automatically reset the time themselves.The research was carried out by OSS Technology and it gives an insight into how physically winding the clocks back and fiddling with our watches will soon be a thing of the past.For the  per cent of Brits who say they still own analogue devices, at least  per cent of them have at least one device at home that is an hour out.And for a third of those polled, ignorance is bliss because they don’t even know that British Summer Timeis going to end.OSS Technology surveyed , adults across the UK to find out how they are preparing for the time change this Sunday.This year, Sunday, March , marked the start of BST and clocks went forward by one hour.The change ensures that there is more daylight in the evenings and less in the mornings.Greenwich Mean Timewill resume from the last Sunday in October– when the clocks go back one hour again.To avoid confusion, many use the phrase spring forward in spring, fall back in fall to remember when the clocks change.Clocks around Britain will go back at am on October , this is when BST goes and weto the classic GMT.

title: used condom co op fridge
story: Kenny Moore and friend Michael Bradshaw were disgusted when they made the discovery while on their lunch break in Holton-le-Clay Co-op in Lincs.And the pair claim workers had rled through the fridge and discovered another contraceptive.Kenny, , said: I went into the shop to get a meal deal out of the fridge.I got my sandwich, my pork pie, went to get my drink. As I grabbed my Lucozade, something hit my hand.It was a condom.Sickened Michael, , ended up skipping his lunch after the stomach-churning discovery and doused himself in hand sanitiser.He raised the alarm with staff, who made the second condom discovery at around midday yesterday.Both have now vowed not to shop in the store again - but said the team could send them a box of Roses to make up for the grisly find.A spokeswoman for Lincolnshire Co-op said: This is obviously very concerning. As soon as we were made aware of the issue our team began taking extensive action.We will be launching a full investigation into what happened here and will be acting on the findings as appropriate.“The store team themselves have been shaken by this and we would encourage anyone in the local community who knows anything that may help our investigations to come forward and let us know.”

title: cambodia metal sky alien invasion
story: Locals in Preah Vihear province said they heard a loud bang at around am local time before running outside and discovering dozens of pieces of aluminium.Fragments of the UFO had clattered into homes causing damage over an area of more than six miles, but no people were injured.Villagers collected the fragments of the flying object and reported the mystery to police, who have been unable to identy the wreckage.The discovery - just  miles north of an area where missing flight MH was believed to have been seen in the jungle - has sparked fears that the metal could be from an alien aircraft.Villager Sok Nol in the Srayong commune of Kulen district where the pieces were found said: I heard a big noise in the morning. I was shocked and thought something bad had happened.When I went to look there was one big piece in a field, and other smaller pieces around. We thought an aeroplane had crashed but there was no big engine.Now I think that it has come from space and landed in our village. Its confusing because nobody knows what it is.Preah Vihear provincial police chief major general Yin Chamnan said  pieces of aluminium and rubber had been recovered in the village.He said that regional police had not yet been able to identy source and a team of specialists would investigate the pieces.He said that there were fragments weighing more than kg.He said: Maybe these fragments are parts of a drone that someone flew. The parts were not relatively big.We have found more than  fallen fragments of aluminium and rubber. But, we are continuing the search and are collecting further information from the people at the scene.Earlier this week, British video producer Ian Wilson scrapped his attempt to scour the Cambodian jungle in search of missing Malaysian flight MH after an aeroplane shape was seen on Google maps.

title: picky roommate ad landlord no vegans
story: The picky proprietor, listed as Alex, has been accused of discrimination after he banned vegans from applying to rent his flat and told grubby flatmates to forget it.His SpareRoom advert that went live on Monday, warning viewers in block capitalsyoure vegan, dont bother before continuing to list other requirements.His duplex apartment, located in Manchesters Northern Quarter, boasts a spacious living room, bathroom and two bedrooms for £ per month.The live-in landlord, , even did his best to scare off dirty flatmates by writingyoure untidy in general - forget it.Alex brags that he is a pretty nice guy, laidback and not your typical landlord that everyone hates - though goes on to warn prospective tenants not to take the p**s.He also claims he cant be arsed with a   hour party animal either, sorry.Now the Vegan Society are urging the landlord to reconsider his decision and reminded Alex that vegans have excellent cooking skills.Alexs original advert reads: Hi, Im Alex and Ill be living with you as a live in landlord.I’m  years old. I’d like to think I’m a pretty nice guy - definitely not your typical landlord that everyone hates, I’m pretty laidback with everything, but don’t take the p***.***IF YOURE VEGAN, DONT BOTHER***My room is right above yours, on the second floor. On your level, there’s a kitchen, a bathroom and the front door. My bedroom is next to the living room upstairs.There is no wardrobe in your room, only a set of drawers, a small table and a bed which is enough for most people.There won’t be a TV in the living room until at least December, as I’m only just coming back from being abroad for  months. I’ll buy one as soon as I can.I can tell you right now thatyou aren’t keen on doing your own dishes oryou’re untidy in general - forget it.I cant be arsed with a   hour party animal either, sorry.After being made aware of the advert, the Vegan Society pointed out that had Alex been trying to rent out the whole house, such discrimination would not be appropriate.However he enjoys a loophole as a live-in landlord and is able to ensure only meat eaters are welcome.A spokesperson for The Vegan Society said: “While we can appreciate that the landlord was aiming for the advert to be humorous, we don’t quite understand why he would be opposed to living with a vegan.“It’s worth noting thathe was letting out a whole house, discrimination would not be appropriate but there is an exemption in certain situations such asyou’re a live-in landlord.“It is a well-known fact that many vegans are good cooks who pay attention to what goes into their meals.Vegans are often happy to cook for their housemates too, which we think might make Alex reconsider his decision to ban them from his home.”SpareRoom, the website where Alex posted his advert, have called his views contradictory and claim they prefer users to be a bit more positive in how they word things.A spokesperson for SpareRoom said: When people are advertising for someone to live with it’s common for them to have preferences in terms of their new flatmate.Saying ‘I’m pretty laid back with everything’, followed by ***IF YOU’RE VEGAN DON’T BOTHER*** feels like a bit of a contradiction.Ultimately, we’d always prefer itour users take people on the basis of who they are, rather than which ‘boxes’ they tick.When Alex was approached for comment, he said: Are you interested in the room or not

title: zante earthquake west coast greece 6 8 magnitude
story: The massive tremor struck in the dead of night on the country’s west coast, with the holiday isle of Zante – also called Zakynthos – worst affected.Brit tourists were among those caught up in the tremor, which was also felt in Greeces capital, Athens, and as far away as Italy and even Africa.One holidaymaker from Yorkshire told Sun Online how her terried family were left huddling outside their hotel as the building shook.Tracey Archer tweeted to travel agent Thomas Cook: Please do something!! We are stuck in Zante after an earthquake and everyone is outside the hotel in blankets.There’s babies and young children. Please do something, we’re scared and cold.Tracey, , told The Sun Online: Were terried. We’ve just had another bad aftershock and they keep coming.We were stood outside the hotel for about three hours in the freezing cold, scared.There were young children crying and screaming. We felt a quake about .am and later a larger one half an hour later.Were you affected by the earthquake  Email tips@the-sun or call   Tracey - who is staying at the Smartline Margarita Hotel with her partner Luke,  - said the quake knocked sinks off walls, pulled air con units down and shted furniture.She added: The bed was shaking violently for minutes.My partner and I screamed and grabbed each other and he put a pillow over us to protect us as we thought the ceiling would cave.Laura Sallabanks, , from Coningsby, Lincs, said her nine-year-old daughter was left “shaken” after rushing out of their accommodation in the Alykes area.She told Sun Online: “We woke up to a smaller quake, half hour before the big one which set things rattling in our rooms.“The big quake lasted a couple of minutes and felt like the whole building was swaying around us.“There was a loud rumble. I ran through to grab my daughter who is nine and we all rushed to get outside where we sat with the locals for a couple of hours.”The mum described “items thrown from shelves” and the quake leaving “cracked floor tiles and slabs”, admitting: “My poor heart is still pounding!”She added: “We can still feel aftershocks now after eight hours, which feel like dull rumbles.”Other Brits took to social media to tell of their experiences.One wrote: “Standing outside the hotel no clue what to do   Cracks in the building no @ThomasCookUK rep or advice.”Another posted: “Actual earthquake in #zante #zakynthos #kalamaki never experienced anything like that in my le!“Room shook for  seconds, followed by a longer period of vigorous shaking and with items falling off the bedside and around the room.“Electricity is off and everyone evacuated.”" data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   quake.png stripallw" "" width""  " data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   quake.png stripallw" "" width""  " data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   quake.png stripallw" "" width"" A third tweeted: “Go to #Greece they said ... have a Nice relaxing holiday they said.“#Zante is lovely this time of year they said...then a cheeky  #earthquake on a full moon.“Rather unsettling. But buildings and the people here seem to be made of strong stuff so... So far, so good.”And another said: Me and my partner are staying in Zante, it woke my partner up, and weve had three aftershocks much smaller, the larger quake has moved several items around the room.Tremors were felt as far away as Italy and AlbaniaDramatic images show how the quake tore tarmac in half near the island’s harbour.Power was lost in the capital and main town, also called Zakynthos.The fire service said rockfalls were reported in another part of the island, where boulders crashed onto a packed beach sending tourists fleeing just last month.And part of a church wall collapsed on the mainland town of Pyrgos, in the southern Peloponnese area.Several of people were treated for minor injuries.Civil protection agency press spokesman Spyros Georgiou said a precautionary tsunami warning was issued.He added: “Were checking out the villages on the island, where there are several older buildings.“The lack of electricity is a problem, but technicians are trying to restore power.”Initial reports suggested the quake hit the Ionian sea, just off the western coast of Greece at just before pm local time.The Greek tourist island, popular with Brits, is understood to have been the epicentre.Greece lies in one of the worlds most earthquake-prone regions, with thousands of quakes recorded every year.But few cause injuries or signicant damage. In , a magnitude . quake on the outskirts of Athens killed  people.Zante has had severe earthquakes in the past, and as a result has a very strict building safety code.

title: debenhams 500m pothole in the road to reinvention
story: This, runs the message, is the unnished truth. title: the 2018 budget what to look out for
story: The Resolution Foundation think-tank suggested this week that Mr Hammond would need to find an extra #bn by   to live up to the ending austerity pledge. He also needs to find an extra #.bn a year in real terms to fund Mrs Mays NHS commitments.The chancellor is also under pressure from Tory backbenchers to cancel a planned increase in income tax allowancesin order to reverse cuts to Universal Credit for Britains lowest earners.But in such a fraught political environment it is unlikely that the chancellor will do very much at all this time around.Fiscally, its dficult to calculate how much the public finances will be affected by Brexit when we still dont knowthe UK will be leaving with a deal or not.Politically, Mrs May is in a very dangerous place in parliament, with both the DUP and Tory MPs threatening rebellions over Brexit.Against that backdrop, Mr Hammond will be hoping to get through the budget without incident. Ending austerity will have to wait. HEALTHPaul Kelso, health correspondentI am looking out for... what the plan is for public health and social care. The NHS is in the unfamiliar position of wondering "how", not "how much" from the budget.The government has already promised the health service a .% funding increase for the next five years, and indicated that taxes will rise to pay for it.But that only covers core NHS spending, and so the chancellors speech will be watched closely for information on other crucial areas, including public health budgets and social care.Both of those are currently in the gt of local government, but without investment in them, demand for NHS services will continue apace.NHS executives are currently working on a long-term plan, outlining what the public can expect from the health service.It is effectively a justication for the tax increase the chancellor will announce in the budget, but we wont see it for several weeks afterwards.Given the ambition of delivering improved cancer and mental health treatment, it is likely compromises will be required in areas including non-urgent care. ECONOMYEd Conway, economics editorI am looking out for...the chancellor manages to break out of the restraints imposed on him.Ever since the era of Gordon Brown, the chancellor has had two big annual opportunities to deliver major changes to the UK economy.When he came into office, Philip Hammond changed that: as well as shting the budget from the spring into the autumn, he proclaimed that from now on there would only be a single major fiscal event every year. One change to sht the needle every  months.The great irony is that now Mr Hammonds single shot has come around, he is so penned in that there is not all that much he can do.The biggest elephant in the room is Brexit. We are still days, week, possibly months away from having a deal on Brexit - and until that is determined, there is little point in the chancellor making major fiscal plans.The second issue is that without a majority, the government has little scope to introduce radical policies. The final constraint is that the prime minister has also laid down some crucial red lines.In her party conference speech earlier this month, Mrs May promised to end austerity. She has also committed to considerable extra spending on the NHS.Those two commitments mean Mr Hammond has little leeway. Happily, tax receipts have come in much stronger than expected in recent months, so he no longer needs to raise taxes considerably to fulfil those aims.The budget will be a steady-as-she-goes affair. A survival budget.

title: esther mcvey shuts door journalist
story: NewsEsther McVey shuts door on journalist askingTory minister is in denial about Universal CreditThe Work and Pensions Secretary fled TV cameras this morning after an audit report blasted her for presiding over a "department in denial"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAn audit report blasted her for presiding over a department in denial "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tory Esther McVey has shut the door on a journalist askingshe is in denial about the hated benefit shake-up Universal Credit . The Work and Pensions Secretary fled TV cameras this morning after an audit report blasted her for presiding over a department in denial.More than .million people are on the six-in-one benefit, with more than  new Jobcentres hit by Christmas, as its blamed for food banks use and rent debts. In a damning report today, the Commons Public Accounts Committee said the Tory “fortress mentality” is failing claimants who are struggling to adapt. Meg Hillier, who chairs the PAC, said: “This report provides further damning evidence of a culture of indference at DWP - a department disturbingly adrt from the real-world problems of the people it is there to support.  “Its apparent determination to turn a deaf ear to the concerns of claimants, frontline organisations and Parliament is of real concern. Yet confronted by Sky News at her office today, Ms McVey denied she was in denial. Askedshe had any comment, the Tatton MP told Sky News - without stopping to talk - there is but Ive just got to get into work. Askedshe had presided over a culture of denial, she turned her back to the camera and replied: Absolutely not.  Were speaking with everybody at the moment, hence Ive started new partnership arrangements with the PAC and the Citizens Advice Bureau. Askedshe could repeat her comments - which were muffled due to her walking away at the time - she replied: I can but Im going inside. She then shut the door with a firm thud.A Downing Street spokeswoman today said Theresa May has full confidence in the Work and Pensions Secretary.

title: philip green lord hain defends
story: NewsPhilip Green: Lord Hain defends outing Topshop tycoon as man behind Daily#MeToo gagging order rowThe Labour peer told BBC Twos Newsnight he had received "overwhelming support - particularly from women" after naming the businessman under parliamentary privilegeShareByDavid HughesAndrew Woodcock:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video lord-hain-defends-decision-out-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLord Peter Hain has defended his decision to out Sir Philip Green as businessman behind the British #MeToo gagging order row. The former cabinet minister used parliamentary privilege to name the Topshop tycoon after the Dailywas barred from publishing allegations of sexual harassment and racial abuse against him. The paper wants to reveal confidential information from five employees, who have been prevented from discussing their claims by non-disclosure agreements . But Sir Philip categorically and wholly denied being guilty of any unlawful sexual or racist behaviour, in a statement issued hours after the Labour peers dramatic intervention in the House of Lords.  Lord Hain told BBC Twos Newsnight he had received overwhelming support - particularly from women. Lord Hain told peers he had been contacted by someone intimately involved in the case and felt it was his duty to use parliamentary privilege to name Sir Philip. Having been contacted by somebody intimately involved in the case of a powerful businessman using non-disclosure agreements and substantial payments to conceal the truth about serious and repeated sexual harassment, racist abuse and bullying, which is compulsively continuing, I feel its my duty under parliamentary privilege to name Philip Green as the inidual in question given that the media have been subject to an injunction preventing publication of the full details of a story which is clearly in the public interest, he said.  Lord Hain later confirmed his statement referred to the chairman of Arcadia Group, whose brands include Topshop, Topman, Wallis, Evans, Burton, Miss Selfridge, Dorothy Perkins and Outfit. Sir Philip responded in a statement, saying: I am not commenting on anything that has happened in court or was said in Parliament today. To the extent that it is suggested that I have been guilty of unlawful sexual or racist behaviour, I categorically and wholly deny these allegations. Arcadia and I take accusations and grievances from employees very seriously and in the event that one is raised, it is thoroughly investigated. Arcadia employs more than , people and in common with many large businesses sometimes receives formal complaints from employees. In some cases these are settled with the agreement of all parties and their legal advisers. These settlements are confidential so I cannot comment further on them.  The principle of parliamentary privilege means that MPs and peers cannot be sued for libel for comments made in the Houses of Parliament, and offers protection to media outlets reporting those comments. Speaking to Newsnight, Lord Hain explained his decision to speak out, saying: What concerned me about this case was wealth, and power that comes with it, and abuse. And that was what led me to act in the way that I did. Its for others to judge whether Ive been right or wrong. But theres no point in being in Westminster - which is the sovereign centre of the British constitution, has sovereignty and with it the parliamentary privilege that is a privilege ...you never discharge thatyou never deploy the precious rights of parliamentary privilege.  He stressed that the cloak of privilege should be used extremely carefully with integrity and very responsibly - never just loosely. On Wednesday, Theresa May pledged to hasten measures to improve regulation around so-called gagging clauses in response to questions about the case. The Prime Minister said some employers are using NDAs unethically as she criticised abhorrent sexual harassment in the workplace. Mrs Mays spokesman declined to comment on Lord Hains statement. Askedthe PM feels it is acceptable for parliamentarians to use the protection of privilege to put information into the public domain in this way, the spokesman said: The rules of parliamentary privilege are a matter for Parliament and how they exercise these rules is obviously a matter for inidual members.  Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable said Sir Philip narrowly and luckily escaped losing his knighthood over the pensions scandal. And he added: If these allegations are correct, he should certainly be stripped of his knighthood. Labour equalities spokeswoman Dawn Butler said: While much of the focus in the coming days will be on this man and his alleged actions, let us also pay tribute to survivors of sexual abuse and harassment, who are too often silenced and cannot command an army of lawyers to fight their corner. NDAs should never be used to suppress allegations of criminal behaviour. If the current law doesnt protect the voices of survivors, the next Labour government will legislate to do so. Conservative MP James Cleverly said Lord Hains action had shown people must now realise that injunctions and super-injunctions are nothing more than a good way to part with large sums of money and a bad way to keep things secret.

title: sir philip green faces further
story: NewsSir Philip Green faces further calls to be stripped of his knighthood over sexual harassment claimsThe tycoon was today unmasked in Parliament by Lord Hain as the figure accused of trying to gag the allegationsShareByAndrew GregoryPolitical EditorNick SommerladNicola BartlettAmy-Clare Martin:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsSir Philip Green is knighted in  for services to retail industry "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSir Philip Green faces further calls to be stripped of his knighthood over sexual harassment claims. The tycoon was today unmasked in Parliament by Lord Hain as the figure accused of trying to gag the allegations. Greens expensive efforts to remain anonymous over sexual harassment claims were ended in Parliament today. Veteran politician Peter Hain used parliamentary privilege to name Green in the Lords – something he would not be able to do outside the House. And the move sparked further demands for businessman Green to be stripped of his shyknighthood after he managed to cling on to it despite the collapse of the BHS chain with the loss of , jobs and a poundmillion pension black hole.  The -year-old had used a court injunction to stop the Dailyfrom revealing he was the figure who agreed financial settlements and non-disclosure agreements with alleged victims of sexual shyharassment, racist abuse and bullying. Green denies all the allegations. Sir Vince Cable said: “I find it dficult to see how he could credibly hold on to an honour in these circumstances. “He narrowly and luckily escaped losing his knighthood over the pensions scandal. If these allegations are correct, he should certainly be stripped of his knighthood.” Labour MP Clive Lewis added: “If he has used his wealth to gag people and given the disgrace of what happened on the BHS pensions, how that was basically asset-stripped and the lives of thousands potentially ruined, I think it says a lot about this countrysomeone like that can be given a shyknighthood and keep their knighthood having the reputation they do.” Neil Saunders, managing director of industry experts Global Data Retail, warned the claims against Topshop boss Green could be potentially damaging to his business.  He said: “While the allegations are only claims and have not yet been legally proven, Philip Green’s association with them is highly damaging for both him and the retail businesses he owns. “Unless the claims are proven to be  then there is no coming back. The stench of sexual misconduct lingers for le.” Women and Equalities Select Committee chair Maria Miller blasted judges for granting the gagging order. She said: “Given the huge influence Philip Green wields in the world of business it is surprising the Court of Appeal decided it wasn’t in the public interest to make public the string of payments that have been made.” Thespent eight months investigating the claims against Green. But on Tuesday, it was prevented from revealing the existence of a string of non-disclosure deals after a ruling by senior judge Sir Terence Etherton, the Master of the Rolls.  Green hired a team of seven lawyers and reportedly spent nearly pound, on legal fees. But Labour minister Lord Hain told the Lords: “I had been contacted by someone intimately involved in the case of a powerful shybusinessman using non-disclosure agreements and substantial payments to conceal the truth about serious and repeated sexual harassment, racist abuse and bullying. “I feel it’s my duty under shyparliamentary privilege to name Philip Green as the inidual in shyquestion given that the media have been subject to an shyinjunction preventing shypublication of the full details of this story which is clearly in the public interest.” Lord Hain said later: “I’m not disputing judges’ shyresponsibilities or timing or anything like that, that’s a matter for the judiciary. “I’m just charging my duty as a parliamentarian and what concerned me about this case was wealth, and power that comes with it, and abuse. “And that was what led me to act in the way that I did.”  Arcadia chief Green broke his silence last night to insist: “To the extent that it is suggested that I have been guilty of unlawful sexual or racist behaviour, I categorically and wholly deny these allegations.” The interim court injunction made it illegal to reveal Green’s identity or name his companies, as well as details of the claims against him. The -page ruling states that in five cases “substantial payments” were made to five people who accused Green of “discreditable conduct”. It added: “In all five cases the complaints were compromised by settlement agreements under which shysubstantial payments were made to the complainants.”  Under these shyagreements “both sides undertook to keep confidential the subject matter of the complaints”. The ruling did not shyidenty any iniduals but stated that “the most serious allegations of specic and particularised incidents are denied” by the businessman. Theprovided the court with “no corroboration of those incidents but only the allegations of the employees”. A previous High Court ruling, which could only be reported this week, found in favour of the , stating that “in all the circumstances, the public interest in publication outweighs any confidentiality attaching to the information”. But the Appeal Court ruled this week the judge “left out of account the important and legitimate role played by non-disclosure shyagreements in the consensual shysettlement of disputes”. It ruled: “There is a real prospect that publication by thewill cause immediate, substantial and possibly irreversible harm to all of the claimants.” Green’s lawyers Schillings have worked for shyCristiano Ronaldo, Lance Armstrong and Ryan Giggs, all who have used NDAs or shyinjunctions to silence those accusing them of wrongdoing.

story: NewsUniversal Credit: Thousands face having no payments this Christmas - how to make sure youre not hitThe new benefit Universal Credit is rolling out to millions, and many could find themselves caught in a gap over Christmas. Heres how to avoid being caught outShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsYou could be in a five-week gap over Christmas - make sure youre not caught on the hop "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUniversal Credit is rolling out to about , people a month, leaving a trail of rent debt and food banks in its wake. The six-in-one benefit is meant to make welfare easier and fairer, but its been bundled up with cuts that MPs warn cause unacceptable hardship.The Department for Work and Pensionshas been blasted for being in denial about the problems by Parliaments public spending watchdog. Meanwhile Christmas is fast approaching - and thousands of families face the risk of a financial gap over the holiday season. Thats because there is a standard five-week wait for your first payment when you start claiming Universal Credit.  Soyou start claiming at the end of November or midway through December, you are unlikely to get your first payment until the New Year. And to make matters worse, UC is being introduced in more than  Jobcentres in a final two-month rush before the end of the year. Redcar and Clevelands council leader Sue Jeffrey has claimed up to  families moving to Universal Credit face Christmas without money in her area alone. She told the Teesside Gazette: They will also not have access to the services who might be able to support them.  “This council, for example closes down over Christmas, and there are range of other organisations that will do the same.” But there is a way to avoid being high and dry, and not everyone is affected. So how do you knowyoure hit, and what action should you take  Heres a guide. What is Universal Credit   One system to replace six benefits: Child Tax Credit, Working Tax Credit, Jobseekers Allowance, Income Support, Employment Support Allowance and Housing Benefit. Tory minister Iain Duncan Smith launched it in  to make work pay, by ensuring your benefits taper away slowly as you earn more salary, rather than vanishing in one go. Am I being moved on to Universal Credit   If you are on one of the above benefits, then yes. But this article only deals with people who are being moved onto Universal Credit at the moment. Universal Credit is rolling out in two phases, and its important to know which one youre in. The first phase is already happening now - the second phase isnt. The first phase - people who ARE affected New claimants and existing claimants whose circumstances change are being put on the benefit right now. This process started in one area at a time, with each Jobcentre having its own launch date. The first Jobcentre launched UC in November . Now its in almost every Jobcentre, and the final  will launch it in November and December . That means that by this Christmas, anyone who makes a new claim anywhere in Britain will be put on Universal Credit. There were already .million people in this position by September . By May  it will be million, and by December  itll be million. The second phase - people who ARENT affected Up to million existing claimants will move onto UC later through a process called managed migration. They are not affected by the issue in this article. Unlike in the first phase, they will be able to access a poundbillion transition fund to ensure their benefit payments dont suddenly drop. They will also mostly not start moving over until summer .Only , people are being moved over in the first year from July  after Tory ministers slowed the process down. But beware - evenyoure an existing claimant, you could still be moved earlierthe DWP decides youve had a change of circumstances. So why the focus on Christmas   Campaigners fears are greatest when Universal Credit is new to an area. It means Jobcentre staff are dealing with their first cases under the new benefit, which its claimed could lead to teething problems and delays. So while anyone who claims from late November faces a wait over Christmas, its those in new Universal Credit areas who are being highlighted. There will be  Jobcentres launching Universal Credit in November and December. We have listed those areas in full at the bottom of this article. How do I ensure Im not left high and dry   Its important to know the DWP has a system to ensure your money is not cut off. Its called an advance payment. As soon as you make a claim for Universal Credit, you can apply for % of your first months payment. You apply through your online account or Jobcentre work coach, and it should arrive within five days. If you need help applying, call  . But theres a huge drawback - you have to pay the advance back out of your future benefits. The repayments can be spread over  months and there is no interest. Elsewhere, housing benefit will also keep being paid for the first two weeks of a Universal Credit claim, to help bridge the gap. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. title: loud mums tv seized begs
story: NewsNuisance neighbour who had noisy TV seized begs court toit because her baby needs to learn from itJemma Huntes Polaroid television, speakers and LG sound bar were taken away from her after neighbours complainedShareCommentsByEmma DavisonChris kitching:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsJemma Huntes TV and other electronics will be destroyed "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum whose TV was seized because she was too loud says she needs it back because her babys development has deteriorated without it. Jemma Huntes Polaroid television, speakers and LG sound bar were taken away from her after neighbours complained about the noise coming from her Huddersfield home. The -year-old had repeatedly ignored a noise abatement notice served due to the amplied sound, loud voices and banging. But her plea for the TV to be ed was denied by magistrates and the electronics will now be destroyed, the Examiner reports. Kirlees Magistrates ordered the confiscation of the equipment after Hunte refused to comply with the notice.  It was seized from her home on August  but she pleaded with magistrates: “Please can I have the TV back  “Ive got a baby and his development has deteriorated because weve had no TV.” Hunte pleaded guilty to seven charges of failing to comply with an abatement notice dated between June and August this year.Tahir Han, prosecuting on behalf of Kirklees Council, said that a neighbour complained about noise coming from Huntes property, including loud music, raised voices and banging.In April a further complainant was made to the council and its Environmental Health team then attended to investigate. Loud noise coming from the property was observed on June  and then on June  Hunte was served with an abatement notice requiring her keep it down. When she continued to ignore this notice council officials attended and seized the equipment used in the offending, Mr Han said. Related video: A single mum on Universal Credit can’t afford school unorms for kids  He added: “Theres an application for the items seized to be forfeited and disposed of by the council.” Hunte asked for the TV back but said that the sound bar and speakers belonged to a friend. She said: “The music was coming from the sound bar but Ive never, ever played music off the TV. “I had surround sound but I sold it after the complaints. My friend left the sound bar at my house and I used it for the music. “I know I shouldnt have. Please can I have the TV back ” Kirklees Magistrates fined Hunte pound and ordered her to pay pound prosecution costs plus pound victim surcharge. This will be paid out of her benefits at a rate of pound per fortnight. They granted the councils application for the seized electronic equipment to be destroyed. Chairman of the bench Philip Morris told her: “You had many opportunities to comply with this order. “You didnt take them and therefore we are granting the application for the disposal of the items listed, including the TV.

title: meghan markle curtsy queen tonga
story: NewsMeghan Markle curtsies to Queen of Tonga as she and Harry bid farewell before ing to SydneyThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex visited the Royal Palace for an audience with King Tupou VI and his we Queen Nanasipau’uShareCommentsByRussell MyersAnn GripperExecutive EditorNatalie Evans:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video meghan-opts-bold-blue-dress-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShes the actress who became a princess, but Meghan Markle still knows how to show respect to royalty. The Duchess of Sussex politely curtsied as she greeted the Queen of Tonga following a whistle-stop stay on the island. Before heading back to Sydney for the Invictus Games, Harry and Meghan were driven to the Royal Palace for an audience with King Tupou VI and his we Queen Nanasipau’u. The couple entered the wooden, whitewashed palace and spent around  minutes inside with the royals.  The Duke and Duchess signed a visitor’s book before they left and then posed outside with the king and queen for photographers. They also shook hands with the Tongan ruler and his we, Meghan, noticeably curtsying to the Queen. Meghan injected a splash of colour into Friday afternoons royal engagements with a bold blue dress. She had a quick outfit change, ditching her earlier striped frock for a pound shirt dress by American designer brand Veronica Beard.  The royal couple visited Tupou College, where they dedicated two forest reserves to the Queens Commonwealth Canopy. The QCC is a project which sees countries of the Commonwealth designate areas of indigenous forest to be preserved in perpetuity, with  of the  member countries already taking part.  Speaking at Tupou College, the duke said: Tonga is leading by example and understands deeply the impact of environmental changes because they directly affect these islands. Planting trees and conserving forests helps us in so many ways. It is a simple but effective way to restore and repair our environment, clean the air, protect habitat and enhance our health and wellbeing.  We are so very grateful to you for this contribution of the Toloa Forest Reserve and the Eua National Park Forest Reserve. During a ceremony which featured hymns, with Harry appearing to sing along to Guide Me O Thou Great Redeemer, the duke and duchess smiled at each other. Harry was then taken on a tour of the forest while the schools band and pupils continued to sing.  Earlier on Friday, Meghan wore a Martin Grant dress with a large bow covering her baby bump as she joined Prince Harry to meet the Tongan Prime Minister. The couple were met by more than  civil servants wearing red and black shirts and traditional outfits, as they entered the St George Government Buildings for a meeting with PM ʻAkilisi Pohiva and his cabinet. One child held a sign saying free hugs which Meghan spotted and smiled. The couple then took the lt to meet the Prime Minister, who was at last nights black tie banquet with the Tongan royal family and the Sussexes, with Harry asking Did you enjoy last night  The entertainment was very good. The remainder of the meeting was held in private.  Meghans pound, cotton dress is from the SS  Resort Collection. It is described as having a button-down silhouette, mandarin collar, circle skirt and belted accent at the waist. Meghan has previously worn a trench coat from the collection during this tour. The couple later had floral garlands placed round their necks as they arrived for a noisy celebration of Tongan youth and culture. Harry and Meghan joined Princess Angelika and Prince Ata, Kings Tupou VIs son and daughter, at the Faonelua Centre, showing products such as traditional mats and tapa cloth, carvings, bracelets made from whale bone and wood. Inside, they sat on two throne-like chairs in the centre of the room, while Princess Angelika delivered a short address and called the couple an inspiration to the youth of the Commonwealth for shining a light on youth empowerment.  She said: Your visit today draws attention to the fundamentals of todays youth, youth leadership, youth empowerment and addressing the social, economic and environmental challenges of our region. Your visits inspires and has been an inspiration for the youth of Tonga to be the best they can be. You are a beacon of hope to us all. Outside, the couple were given a Taovalawhich signies Tongan respect to the higher ranks. They met local Tongan traders and craftsmen as the Masani group of singers and dancers performed island music and songs. Harry appeared to do a little jig as the music started. The Sussexes will also visit the oldest secondary school in the Pacic where two forest reserves will be dedicated to the Queens Commonwealth Canopy Project.  They will then fly to Sydney from Fuaamotu airport in the afternoon. And they are straight back into engagements in Australia as they attend the Australian Geographic Society Awards at the Shangri-La Hotel in the evening. At last nights banquet with King Tupou VI and Queen Nanasipau’u Nuku’alofa, Harry said he felt ashe was visiting an extended family and delivered a message from the Queen. Her message was: Your Majesties, it gives me great pleasure that my grandson and his we are visiting The Kingdom of Tonga. Our two families have enjoyed a deep and warm friendship over many years, and I hope that our close relationship continues with the next generation. To this day, I remember with fondness Queen Salotes attendance at my own Coronation, while Prince Philip and I have cherished memories from our three wonderful visits to your country in ,  and . In the months and years ahead, I wish Your Majesties and the people of Tonga every good fortune and happiness.  The duke had high praise for Tongas talents in many dferent fields. He said: Tongan soldiers served with our allies during the First and Second World Wars and later independently to offer support in Iraq and Afghanistan. Tongan hospitality is world renowned your islands are stunningly beautul offering tourists rugged coastlines, humpback whales and coral reefs. Tongas sporting prowess is legendary you are formidable on the rugby pitch , and you were the first Pacic island nation to win a medal at the Olympics! Is there no end to your talents  Tongan artists such as Uili Lousi are winning international awards and your magnicent artefacts were a highlight at the recent Oceania exhibition in London, which my we enjoyed very much when she opened it. For a small population you have a very large presence on the world stage - a product of your talent and drive. story: NewsThree things Meghan Markle insisted on when designing wedding dress - and the small hitch with flowersThe Duchess of Sussexs stunning Givenchy bridal gown - created by Clare Waight Keller - is the star attraction of a new exhibition about the royal wedding at Windsor CastleShareCommentsByTony JonesAmber Hicks:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video first-look-meghan-markles-dress-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle has revealed for the first time exactly how she called the shots when designing her wedding dress. The Duchess of Sussex, , was adamant on three specic details she wanted the exquisite gown to feature as she knew her wedding to Prince Harry, , would be watched by the eyes of the world. The Givenchy dress took , hours - equivalent to  days - to make by a team of . And when Meghan walked down the aisle of St Georges Chapel at Windsor Castle on May  she looked every inch the perfect bride.  Pregnant Meghan said designer Clare Waight Keller respected her vision for the dress, from the shape of the neckline to theof the sleeves - and recognised the importance of tailoring as the outfit had to be modest. But Meghan insisted the dress should have a bateau neckline, cropped sleeves, and a timeless feeling. The bridal gown is the star attraction of a new Windsor Castle exhibition about the royal wedding, which includes audio commentary recorded for visitors by the duke and duchess. Touching stories behind the couples big day are revealed, from Harry joking about joining the Queen and Meghan for a meeting to choose a tiara, to how a cold Easter meant there were less flowers to pick for his wes wedding bouquet.  Meghan says in the commentary: I had a very clear vision of what I wanted for the day, and what I wanted the dress to look like, and so what was amazing in working with Clare is that sometimes youll find designers try to push you in a dferent direction. But she just completely respected what I wanted to see for the day, and she wanted to bring that to le for me. So I knew at the onset I wanted a bateau neckline, I wanted a cropped sleeve, I wanted a very timeless, classic feeling and, obviously with respect to the environment we were in and St Georges Chapel, being really modest in what it would look like, I knew that the tailoring was so key, because the dress itself would be so covered up.  Meghan says in the commentary she had followed Clare Waight Kellers career for a long time and she ticked all the boxes from being British, to reflect the duchess new home, and a woman, to working for Givenchy as artistic director, a global fashion house which added an international dimension to the big day. Meghans five-metre long silk tulle veil was also embroidered with flowers from each of the  Commonwealth nations. The dress luminosity is down to the double-bonded silk cady - fabric woven on both sides of the loom - which catches the light. Speaking in the commentary Meghan adds: There was a great level of detail that went into the planning of our wedding day.  I think for us, we knew how large the scale of the event would be, so in making choices that were really personal and meaningful, it could make the whole experience feel intimate, even though it was a very big wedding. On her wedding day, Meghan wore Queen Marys diamond and platinum bandeau tiara, lent to the duchess by the Queen, which is part of the exhibition. The duchess described her visit to the head of state to choose a headpiece as an incredibly surreal day. The duke, who joined Meghan for the visit to the Queen, joked in the commentary: Every girls dream to be able to try on a tiara, and, funnily enough, the one that suited the best, the one that looked the best on you without question, I shouldnt have really even been there, but such an incredible loan by my grandmother, it was very sweet.  The brides bouquet, which featured a number of plants and flowers including sweet peas and sprigs of myrtle, was designed by florist Philippa Craddock and has been recreated using articial silk flowers for the exhibition which opens on Friday. The duke and duchess said cold weather earlier in the year meant there were less flowers available for the wedding bouquet from their cottage garden at Kensington Palace. Meghan revealed they had been doing some planting in the fall and said the duke made a really beautul gesture by picking blooms for her on their wedding day.  Harry added: We didnt have as many flowers in our little garden as we had hoped for because I think it snowed at Easter. That kind of ruined the whole thing. But, theyre very much a bouquet of wild flower, wild flower meadows and making sure that we had forget-me-nots in as it was one of my mothers favourite flowers... The dukes Household Cavalry frockcoat made for the wedding is not available for the exhibition but another identical one owned by Harry has been loaned for the display  Also on display are the wedding outfits worn by pageboy Prince George, a miniature version of Harrys coat, and bridesmaid Princess Charlotte, an ivory silk dress by Clare Waight Keller. Harry joked: We had  bridesmaids, page boys under the age of seven which everybody says is impossible to have them behaving, but they did it. Meghan quipped: It was a miracle. A Royal Wedding: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex at Windsor Castle runs from October  to January  at Windsor Castle.

story: NewsPearl Black inquest: CPS reveals driver whose runaway car killed The Voice stars daughter will NOT be chargedPearl died aged  months after a brick wall hit by the Range Rover collapsed on top of her as she walked to the park with her father and baby brotherShareCommentsByLucy Clarke-Billings:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPearl, aged  months, died after a brick wall hit by a Range Rover collapsed on top of her "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe driver of a runaway Range Rover which killed toddler Pearl Black will escape new criminal action - as the Crown Prosecution Service today ruled there is not enough evidence to charge him. Pearl, aged  months, died after the brick wall hit by the Range Rover collapsed on top of her as she walked to the park with her father and baby brother. Lorry driver Andrew Williams, , had been driving his Range Rover before leaving it on a steep driveway. But an inquest yesterday heard Mr Williams did not fully apply handbrake - and the automatic vehicle was not left in park.  Pearls devastated parents Paul and Gemma Black spoke out after coroner Andrew Barkley ruled Pearls death was accidental. Paul, , said that due to a legal loophole in the law Mr Williams could not be prosecuted. But a CPS spokesman has now stated that the decision not to charge Mr Williams came following a thorough review.  The spokesman said: The CPS carried out a thorough review of the evidence and concluded the case failed to meet the evidential test for prosecution. We have explained the reasons behind this decision to Pearls family and our thoughts remain with them. After the inquest Mr Black said he would walk to London to get a bill passed to change the law. He said: The vehicle was mechanically sound. It would not have movedit had been properly secured. Yet a simple loophole of law – that it started its descent on private rather than public land – has stopped us getting justice for our daughter. We shouldn’t be here at the coroner’s court today. We should have been given the justice we deserve at criminal court instead, the law as it stands has prevented any repercussions for what was not a fluke accident and could have been completely avoided had the handbrake been fully applied and the automatic transmission correctly placed in park. This is why we are now calling on the Government to change the law so that no other family has to suffer as we have.  The inquest, in Pontypridd, heard Pearl was with her singer father Paul and her eight-month-old brother Acer when the tragedy happened in August . Mr Black screamed: Shes gone. The wall has crushed her, after the Range Rover ploughed into it in Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales. Tests were carried out on the .-tonne Range Rover after it was recovered from the scene. Investigators found the handbrake of the x had been only been applied two notches - out of a possible six.  The gear lever was between park and reverse. Coroner Andrew Barkley gave a conclusion of accidental death. He said: “Mr Williams said he assumed the gear lever was in park. As far as the application of the brake is concerned, he did not count the number of clicks. Sadly, as we know, that was insufficient. It seems the issue here was very much driver operation.”

title: young boy left devastating scars
story: NewsYoung boy left with devastating scars after being set alight by firework shares heartbreaking messageBrave Ben McCabe, , from Glasgow, now copes with the annual event by pretending its just another dayShareCommentsBySarah WardAmber Hicks:,  OCT NewsBen and mum Amy "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young boy left with devastating scars after being set alight by a stray firework still dreads Bonfire Night seven years after his horric ordeal. Ben McCabe, , who needs treatment every day for his burns, has shared a heartbreaking warning ahead of the popular annual event. He urged: I want people to think about the consequences of setting off these fireworks and how easy it is for something to go wrong - when you dont know what to do. Ben was just four years old when he was left screaming in agony as the firework came hurtling towards him and set his shirt on fire.  He had been watching the pyrotechnics with dad Alan in the suburban cul-de-sac where they live in Glasgow, on November , . After being struck by the firework, Bens dad rushed him into the house and put him in a cold bath, calling we Amy to tell her what had happened. Ben then spent three weeks in hospital and was left with third degree burns and needing skin grafts across his chest and neck. The brave schoolboy says he now copes with the annual event by pretending its just another day.  Last bonfire night I managed to make it to the door to look outside but Im still very scared of them, he said. I usually sit in my room and pretend its just another day. Mum Amy, , who had just clocked onto a sht as a nurse at Glasgows Royal Hospital for Sick Children, recalled the terrying incident. She said: The firework headed straight for Ben and went into his shirt which then caught alight.  He was screaming so loud and no one could believe what had just happened. Alan put him into a cold bath until the ambulance came - there was nothing left of his shirt. Amy ran down the hospital corridor to the AE department to meet the ambulance and spent the next three weeks by Bens bedside. As a parent it was killing me inside seeing him like that. I had to try and keep calm for the family - and for Ben, she said.  He was in hospital for  days and still needs skin grafts and massages four times a day to keep the skins elasticity and that can be really hard going. I am so very proud of my son - he is so much braver than me, and anyone I know. But after the initial horror of the accident and the subsequent medical treatment, the family had to live with the prospect that Ben would be scarred for le - and deal with how it would affect his confidence.  Amy, who now works as a dental technician, said: I was worried about what people would say when they saw his scars and how he would react. There was an incident at the swimming pool when he had his pressure garment on and some boys were staring at him and shouting stuff to him. I was looking around for their parents and at the same time worrying what this would do to Ben. He came over to me and said Mum can you take the garment off - so I did.  He put his chin up and walked past these boys bearing his scars with this presence that made my heart skip a beat of pride. He is so much braver than me. The family found support from The Scottish Burned Childrens Club, and Amy said: Ben is so much more confident and determined and wants to help others. He has an amazing network of friends through the club and I cant describe how much it has helped him.  For myself it has been a Godsend to meet other families with similar stories - to know you are not on your own and that you are actually doing OK. Its like a new family and a forever connection that no one  can understand. You cant buy the support. Deputy Assistant Chief Officer for Prevention and Protection John Miller said: Bonfire Night is typically the services busiest night of the year.  We are appealing to the public to attend organised events rather than do-it-yourself bonfires and fireworks displays. Our firefighters work extremely hard to engage with people of all ages and equip them with the knowledge and the awareness of how to stay safe around bonfires and fireworks.
